cleaned_text: Sacred herb Sacred Herbs are herbs that are considered [sacred](/wiki/Sacred) in some [religions](/wiki/Religion). pagan](/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_paganism), and a form of [basil](/wiki/Basil) called as a [Hindu goddess](/wiki/Hinduism) for its [medicinal](/wiki/Medicinal) value—are utilized in their rites and rituals. Europe[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Sacred_herb&action=edit§ion=1)] Herbs were also considered sacred in European pagan beliefs. The best known example is the [mistletoe](/wiki/Mistletoe). The European mistletoe, Viscum album, figured prominently in [Greek mythology](/wiki/Greek_mythology), and is believed to be [The Golden Bough](/wiki/The_Golden_Bough_(mythology)) [Aeneas](/wiki/Aeneas), ancestor of the god](/wiki/Norse_mythology) [Baldr](/wiki/Baldr) was killed with mistletoe. Mistletoe bears fruit at the time of the [Winter Solstice](/wiki/Winter_solstice_celebration), the birth of the new year, and may have been used in solstitial rites in Druidic Britain as a symbol of immortality. In [Celtic mythology](/wiki/Celtic_mythology) and in [druid](/wiki/Druidry) rituals, it was considered a remedy for barrenness in animals and an antidote to poison, although the fruits of many mistletoes are actually poisonous if ingested as they contain [viscotoxins](/wiki/Viscotoxins). [Verbena](/wiki/Verbena) or Vervain has long been associated with [divine](/wiki/Divinity) and other [supernatural](/wiki/Supernatural) forces. It was called "tears of [Isis](/wiki/Isis)" in [ancient and later on " [ancient Greece](/wiki/Ancient_Greece), it was dedicated to [Eos Erigineia](/wiki/Eos). In the early Christian era, folk legend stated that [Common Vervain](/wiki/Common_Vervain) (V. officinalis) was used to staunch [Jesus](/wiki/Jesus)' wounds after his removal from the [cross](/wiki/Crucifix). It was consequently called "Holy Herb" or (e.g. in "Devil's bane". The [generic name](/wiki/Name_of_a_biological_genus) is the [ancient Roman](/wiki/Ancient_Rome) term for sacrificial herbs considered very powerful. [Pliny the Elder](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder) describes verbena presented on [Jupiter](/wiki/Jupiter_(mythology)) altars; it is not entirely clear if this referred to a Verbena rather than the general term for prime sacrificial herbs. Hazlitt's Faiths and Folklore (1905) quotes Aubrey's Miscellanies (1721), to anti- [stregheria](/wiki/Stregheria) [charms](/wiki/Amulet). In the 1870 The Magic by "Paul Christian" ( [Jean-Baptiste Pitois](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Pitois)) it is employed in the preparation of a [mandragora](/wiki/Mandrake#Magic_and_witchcraft) charm: Would you like to make a Mandragora, as powerful as the [homunculus](little man in a bottle) so praised by [Paracelsus]? Then find a root of the plant called [bryony]. Take it out of the ground on a Monday (the day of the moon), a little time after the vernal equinox. Cut off the ends of the root and bury it at night in some country churchyard in a dead man's grave. For thirty days water it with cow's milk in which three bats have been drowned. When the thirty-first day arrives, take out the root in the middle of the night and dry it in an oven heated with branches of [verbena]; then wrap it up in a piece of a dead man's winding-sheet and carry it with you everywhere. [[3]] Other examples of sacred herbs include [mugwort](/wiki/Mugwort). Pop Culture[ adult novels [The Vampire Diaries](/wiki/The_Vampire_Diaries), author [L. J. Smith](/wiki/L._J._Smith_(author)) uses vervain to humans from [vampires](/wiki/Vampires), [[5]](#cite_note-5) in an extension of vervain's fabled magic-suppression powers against witches. In The Struggle, Volume II, the vampire Stefan instructs the human Elena that vervain can "protect you against bewitchment, and it can keep your mind clear if someone is using Powers against you." [[6]](#cite_note-6) He tells her how it is prepared and used, "Once I've extracted the oil from the seeds, you can rub it into your skin, or add it to a bath. And you can make the dried leaves into a sachet and carry it with you, or put it under your pillow at night", but gives her an unprepared sprig for protection in the meantime.
